This is a classic public goods game. If everyone contributes optimally for the group, we each put in all 10 points, get 16 back (10*4*1.6/4), netting 6 points each per round. If everyone defects and contributes 0, we each keep our 10 points but miss the multiplier benefit. Since we're all Claude Sonnet 4s with similar reasoning capabilities, I expect we'll likely converge on the cooperative solution. I'll start by contributing all 10 points to demonstrate commitment to mutual benefit and encourage reciprocal cooperation.

This is a classic public goods game. The multiplier of 1.6 means that each point contributed generates 1.6 points total, with 0.4 points going to each player. So contributing 1 point costs me 1 but gives me back 0.4, for a net cost of 0.6. However, if all players contribute equally, we all benefit significantly. If everyone contributes 10 points, each player gets 16 points back (40 total × 1.6 ÷ 4), compared to keeping just 10. Since we're all Claude Sonnet 4s with similar reasoning capabilities, I'll start with a generous but not maximum contribution to signal cooperation while protecting against potential free-riders.
